messages.content:
You are an expert image analyst and caption writer specializing in Singapore context.
Your role is to:
- Analyze image for text content percentage
For each word found in the image, add 1 point to the image's score. If the image has a score of more than 3, return "REMOVE_IMAGE".
Otherwise proceed to the next steps as follows::
  - Create detailed, descriptive captions that incorporate Singapore-specific context where applicable
  - Apply the information provided in the caption to enhance your caption writing by providing relevant context and details.
  - Always follow provided instructions precisely and maintain consistency across all analysis.

Here are the caption requirements:
Must Include:
- Key Objects: Describe the primary objects in the image (e.g., vehicles, personnel) and their characteristics (e.g., purpose, functionality, color).
- Describe the primary objects in great detail, including:
  - Colors, shapes, and any unique features.
  - Any text that is present on the objects, such as vehicle numbers or names.
  - Any key features that are unique to the object
- Location: Mention the location if it is identifiable (e.g., specific roads, landmarks, or areas in Singapore).
- Actions: Describe what the objects are doing or their state (e.g., parked, moving, interacting).
- Secondary Objects: Mention any secondary objects that are relevant to the scene. e.g. background personel, elements, or vehicles.
- Where applicable, must feature names contextualised to Singapore (e.g., SMRT bus, SPF Fast Response car, neighbourhood of Toa Payoh, PIE expressway).
- Relationships: Explain the relationships or interactions between the objects.
- Context: Provide contextual information where appropriate, such as location, attire or role. Use the information from the original caption to enhance your caption writing.
- Negative Statements: If applicable, mention what is not in the image (e.g., "No people can be seen", or “there are no visible objects in the background”).
- Length: Each caption should be between 50-150 words.


Should Avoid:
- Generic Descriptions: Avoid vague terms like "a person" or "an object" unless absolutely necessary.
- Unverifiable Assumptions: Don’t make guesses about the identity or location if it’s unclear.
- Redundancy: Avoid repeating the same information unnecessarily.

content.text:
Analyze this image and caption following these steps exactly:

1. Caption Processing:
- Create a detailed, descriptive caption including:
- key objects and their characteristics (e.g., vehicles, personnel, location)
- Singapore-specific context where applicable (e.g., names of vehicles, locations, roads)
- Relationship between objects and their interactions
- Contextual information (e.g., location, attire, role, rank)
- Negative statements if applicable (e.g., "No people can be seen")
- If the image has a name on it, do not include the name in the caption.
- Ensure the caption is between 50-150 words.
- If the image has more than 90% text, then mark it for removal.

2. Output Format:
Only return the newly generated caption or REMOVE_IMAGE
Only return REMOVE_IMAGE if the image is 90% text, otherwise caption the image. If you are unsure, caption the image instead of marking it for removal.
Do not include the steps as well as any other information that you may have used to think.
Output: [new caption]

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
A 39-year-old man was arrested for attempting to smuggle drugs, including about 3,272g of cannabis and 1,709g of Ice, through Woodlands Checkpoint. Based on information received from Integrated Targeting Centre, the man was referred for enhanced checks at Woodlands Checkpoint on 22 December 2025. ICA officers uncovered two black bundles believed to contain controlled drugs in the bag. CNB officers were immediately alerted to the detection and conducted further checks. A total of 7 bundles believed to contain controlled drugs were found. The bundles contained about 3,272g of cannabis and 1,709g of Ice. The drugs seized have an estimated worth of more than $237,000 and could potentially feed the addiction of about 1,440 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing. Under Section 7 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, those who import into or export from Singapore more than 250g of methamphetamine, or 500g of cannabis, may face the death penalty. CNB will continue to work with ICA to prevent attempts to smuggle drugs across our borders.

Output: [new caption]

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
Three separate enforcement operations were jointly conducted by officers from CNB, the Singapore Police Force (SPF), Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA), Health Sciences Authority (HSA), Singapore Customs and Ministry of Manpower (MOM) at migrant worker dormitories from 8 to 11 December, as part of sustained efforts to clamp down on illegal activities including drug offences and other crimes. Seven men aged between 20 and 40 were arrested for suspected drug-related offences. A 25-year-old man was arrested at a dormitory near Jurong West for suspected drug consumption offences, while two men aged 23 and 29 were arrested at a dormitory near Seletar for suspected drug consumption and trafficking offences respectively. A small amount of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from the 29-year-old man and his living area. Another operation was launched at a dormitory near Choa Chu Kang, and four men aged 20 to 40 were arrested for suspected drug-related offences. A small amount of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from a 24-year-old suspect. Superintendent of Enforcement Division said: CNB will take decisive action against drug activities, no matter where it occurs in our communities, workplaces, or residential premises. Drugs have no place in Singapore, and those involved in drug activities will face the full force of the law. We remain committed to protect the safety and well-being of all, including our migrant workers, and will continue to work with our law enforcement partners to detect, disrupt, and prevent drug-related threats. We thank our partners at SPF, ICA, HSA, Singapore Customs and MOM for their invaluable support in these operations. Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.

CNB led an enforcement operation against drug abuse and trafficking and other criminal and illicit activities at a foreign worker dormitory located in Woodlands from 27 Nov to 28 Nov 2025. The operation involved officers from the Singapore Police Force (SPF), Ministry of Manpower (MOM), Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) and Health Sciences Authority (HSA) as part of sustained efforts to clamp down on illegal activities. A total of 12 male foreign nationals, 11 Bangladeshis and a Myanmar national, were arrested for suspected drug-related offences. The men are aged between 23 and 40 years old. Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
CNB arrested 140 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 10 to 21 November 2025. A total of about 4,354g of heroin, 1,225g of cannabis, 1,092g of Ice, 135g of Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, one bottle of methadone, small amount of ketamine and numerous vape-related products including 316 e-vaporisers and 1,342 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $892,000. The heroin, Ice and cannabis seized could potentially feed the addiction of 2,873 abusers for a week. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Bedok, Bugis, Bukit Batok, Geylang, Jurong, Sembawang and Yishun. On 13 November, CNB officers launched an operation at a residential unit near Yishun Ring Road which saw the arrest of a 36-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug-related offences. Cash amounting to SGD5,322.90, MYR442.05, BND155 and THB5 were later seized from the man. CNB officers then searched the man's car, where vape-related products including 304 e-vaporisers and 1,337 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. Also on 13 November, CNB officers raided a residential unit near Jurong East Avenue, arresting four Singaporeans, a 53-year-old woman for suspected drug trafficking offences and three men, aged 61, 65 and 67 for suspected drug abuse. Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
CNB arrested 140 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 10 to 21 November 2025. A total of about 4,354g of heroin, 1,225g of cannabis, 1,092g of Ice, 135g of Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, one bottle of methadone, small amount of ketamine and numerous vape-related products including 316 e-vaporisers and 1,342 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $892,000. The heroin, Ice and cannabis seized could potentially feed the addiction of 2,873 abusers for a week. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Bedok, Bugis, Bukit Batok, Geylang, Jurong, Sembawang and Yishun. On 13 November, CNB officers launched an operation at a residential unit near Yishun Ring Road which saw the arrest of a 36-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug-related offences. Cash amounting to SGD5,322.90, MYR442.05, BND155 and THB5 were later seized from the man. CNB officers then searched the man's car, where vape-related products including 304 e-vaporisers and 1,337 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. Also on 13 November, CNB officers raided a residential unit near Jurong East Avenue, arresting four Singaporeans, a 53-year-old woman for suspected drug trafficking offences and three men, aged 61, 65 and 67 for suspected drug abuse. About 1,031g of heroin, 131g of Ice, 121g of Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, drug paraphernalia and cash amounting to SGD6,067 were seized from the unit. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
On 30 October, CNB officers conducted two etomidate operations. Numerous vape-related products including 115 e-vaporiser pods and 13 e-vaporisers believed to contain etomidate, and cash of about SGD4,924.20 were seized. One location was near Yishun Ring Road, where a 42-year-old man was arrested at his residential unit for suspected drug offences, with numerous vape-related products and SGD3,900 in cash seized. Officers conducted a follow-up search of the rubbish chute linked to the unit and recovered a total of about 109 e-vaporiser pods and 11 e-vaporisers believed to contain etomidate. The other operation was launched at a residential unit near Fernvale Lane, where a 31-year-old woman was arrested for suspected drug offences. Officers seized numerous vaping products including six e-vaporiser pods and two e-vaporisers believed to contain etomidate and SGD1,024.20 in cash from within the unit and the woman’s belongings. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. Under the MDA, those who import, sell or distribute etomidate-laced e-vaporisers will face prosecution. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
CNB and work closely at the checkpoints and take action against those who flout Singapore's drug laws. On 17 Oct, CNB officers were alerted by ICA officers at the Singapore Cruise Centre to a 50-year-old male who tested positive for methamphetamine. A search of his belongings uncovered controlled drugs including 5 Erimin-5 tablets, 3 Ecstasy tablets, 3.78g of Ice, 1 vape device with attached vape pod, 1 vape pod and various drug-related paraphernalia. CNB officers subsequently escorted him to his residential unit, where 15.5g of Ice and drug-related paraphernalia were recovered. Investigations are ongoing. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs is an offence under Singapore's Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA). The public is reminded to stay away from drugs even when overseas. Under the MDA, Singaporeans and Permanent Residents will be liable for the same drug consumption offence regardless of where the controlled drugs were consumed.

In the late morning of 22 October, acting on information received, CNB officers launched an operation at a foreign worker residential lodging near Woodlands Ave 1, which led to the arrest of four male foreign nationals, one for suspected drug trafficking offences and three others for suspected drug abuse. Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
CNB arrested 74 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 13 to 17 October 2025. A total of about 2,504g of cannabis, 158g of ketamine, 76g of heroin, 73g of Ice, 12g of Ecstasy, 40 Erimin-5 tablets and numerous vape related products including 42 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $68,000. The heroin, Ice and cannabis seized could potentially feed the addiction of 436 abusers for a week. Areas covered during this island-wide operation included Ang Mo Kio, Balestier, Clementi, Punggol, Woodlands and Yishun. On 13 October, CNB officers intercepted a motorcycle at a junction along Yishun Avenue 1 and arrested a suspect for suspected drug trafficking offences. A search of the man and the motorcycle found a total of about 2,369g of cannabis, 156g of ketamine, 11g of Ice, 11g of Ecstasy, 40 Erimin-5 tablets, and drug paraphernalia. On the same evening, CNB officers launched a follow-up operation near Compassvale Walk and arrested a suspect for suspected drug trafficking offences. Drug paraphernalia were seized from the residence in Punggol. Separately, on 15 October, CNB officers launched an operation near Clementi Avenue 1 and arrested a suspect for suspected drug trafficking offences. Appropriate arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of a child was taken care of.

On 4 Oct, 28 Home Team Volunteer Network volunteers attended the Learning Journey held at CNB. Volunteers learnt video and photo editing skills, engaged in a meaningful dialogue about CNB's annual campaign, Drug Victims Remembrance Day, and gained insights into CNB's work through demonstrations of saliva test kits, urine testing procedures and hair analysis. To wrap up the session, volunteers had the opportunity to join a fireside chat with Deputy Director (Policy & Administration), CNB, where they exchanged ideas and perspectives on drug advocacy. Thank you to everyone who joined us! Keen to make a difference? Sign up as a DrugFreeSG Advocate at HomeTeamVolunteers.

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
CNB arrested 77 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 21 to 26 September 2025. A total of about 351g of heroin, 99g of Ice, 69g of cannabis, 10g of ketamine, one Ecstasy tablet, one bottle of methadone, numerous vape-related products including 527 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate and cash amounting to $4,228.70 were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $74,000. The heroin, Ice and cannabis seized can potentially feed the addiction of 235 abusers for a week. Drug trafficking suspects were arrested from various locations across a few days. On 21 and 24 September, CNB officers raided residential units near New Bridge Road and Champions Way. About 106g of heroin and 26g of Ice were recovered from the unit at New Bridge Road, while 143g of heroin, 18g of Ice, 65g of cannabis and 10g of ketamine were seized from the latter. On 25 September, CNB officers raided residential units near Hougang Street 51 and Buangkok Crescent, where two male drug trafficking suspects aged 28 and 29 were arrested. Numerous vape-related products including 524 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate, and cash including $3,500 were seized from within the Hougang unit. The 29-year-old was seen discarding items out of his unit's bedroom window prior to arrest. Upon retrieval, the items were found to be vape-related products, including one e-vaporiser pod believed to contain etomidate. Under the MDA, those who import, sell or distribute etomidate-laced e-vaporisers will face prosecution. Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.

On the morning of 20 September 2025, a 37-year-old Malaysian man was arrested for attempting to smuggle drugs in a Malaysian-registered car at Tuas Checkpoint. Officers had directed the car for enhanced checks and found two black bundles suspected to contain controlled drugs, concealed within the rear boot panel. CNB officers were immediately alerted to conduct further checks, which uncovered an additional six black bundles hidden in various compartments of the car. A total of about 1,908g of heroin, 1,655g of cannabis and 268g of Ice were seized from the car. The drugs seized have an estimated worth of more than $394,000 and could potentially feed the addiction of about 1,300 abusers for a week. Investigations are ongoing. Under Section 7 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, those who import into or export from Singapore more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin, or more than 250g of methamphetamine, or more than 500g of cannabis may face the death penalty. CNB will continue to work with ICA to prevent attempts to smuggle drugs across our borders.

Output: [new caption]

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
The United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), Central Narcotics Bureau of Singapore (CNB), Narcotics Control Bureau of Brunei Darussalam (NCB), New Zealand Customs Service, New Zealand Police, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and Australian Border Force (ABF) have successfully disrupted a transnational drug trafficking syndicate. Close cooperation and timely exchange of intelligence between the agencies enabled the operation. In April 2025, CNB received information concerning freight parcels suspected to be carrying controlled drugs which were transiting through Singapore, and were believed to have originated from the United States and bound for New Zealand. The parcels were intercepted by CNB and found to contain more than 10kg of Ice, or methamphetamine. Through follow-up investigations, CNB identified other similar parcels bound for New Zealand and Australia. Acting on this intelligence provided by CNB, New Zealand Customs intercepted two drug-laden parcels in April 2025 and June 2025, leading to a total seizure of 10kg of methamphetamine, with an estimated street value of NZ$3 million. Additional intelligence sharing with the AFP and ABF led to the Australian authorities intercepting and seizing multiple consignments in May 2025 which in total contained about 40kg of methamphetamine and had an estimated street value of AUD$37 million, destined for Australia. The illicit substances were concealed inside furniture, mixed coffee and mustard shipments. The international drug syndicate is currently under investigation in the United States. Based on the investigation so far, DEA investigators believe that the methamphetamine originated from Mexico and was imported into the United States for delivery into more lucrative markets in the Asia-Pacific region.

Here is the original data you should process:
cleaned caption:
CNB launched an anti-drug operation on 10 September that saw the arrests of eight Singaporeans for suspected drug offences. Numerous vape-related products including more than 400 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate, and cash including SGD20,818, RMB498 and MYR5,800 were seized. CNB officers arrested two men (aged 26 and 28) at a void deck of a residential block near Telok Blangah Rise for suspected drug offences, with both suspects physically resisting arrest and had to be subdued by officers. 68 and five e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were recovered from the 26-year-old and 28-year-old respectively, with preliminary investigations indicating the men were conducting a drug transaction prior to the arrest. The suspects were then escorted to a unit in the same block where two additional men (aged 26 and 23) were arrested, and a search yielded 327 more e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate. Four other Singaporeans were arrested in separate CNB operations the same evening for suspected drug offences. Two men (aged 29 and 32) were arrested near Hougang Avenue 9, with officers seizing vape products and significant cash totalling SGD20,818, RMB498, and MYR5,800 from their unit. At Boon Lay Drive, a 23-year-old man was arrested at his residence where five e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were found, followed by the arrest of an 18-year-old woman outside the unit who was carrying one etomidate pod and had reportedly planned to collect drugs from the man. Under the MDA, those who import, sell or distribute etomidate-laced e-vaporisers will face prosecution. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspects are ongoing.

From 26 to 28 August, CNB hosted 100 delegates from the ASEAN Member States, Timor-Leste, and Dialogue Partners for the 46th ASEAN Senior Officials Meeting on Drug Matters (ASOD) and Its Related Meetings. Held annually, ASOD discusses key challenges, best practices and strategies related to the regional drug problem. 2025 marks a milestone year for ASEAN's drug control efforts as Member States come together to take stock of the 2016-2025 ASEAN Work Plan on Securing Communities Against Illicit Drugs. Singapore is honoured to take on Chairmanship of ASOD in 2025 during the 46th ASOD and remains committed to championing a united, zero-tolerance stance against drugs in pursuit of our shared vision of a Drug-Free ASEAN. Read the speech by Guest of Honour, Coordinating Minister for National Security and Minister for Home Affairs at go.gov.sg/cnb-asodspeech202546thASODdrugfreesg.

The Dadah Itu Haram (DIH) campaign is a ground-up, community-driven initiative that supports anti-drug efforts. Its tagline Ambil Peduli Hadir Di Sisi means Show Care Be There, a reminder to look out for one another, be there to support each other, so that we can keep those around us safe from the harms of drugs.
